title: Learn the Brutal Lateral Kneebar and Hiplock from Reversed Closed Guard
description:
In this video, I show two of my favorite leg attacks from reverse closed guard: the lateral kneebar and the hiplock. The lateral kneebar is a strong, direct leg lock that uses a twisting motion to attack the knee joint, while the hiplock uses a similar setup but targets the hip and knee with more of a compression finish. These two attacks are perfect for catching people off guard and adding another layer to your reverse closed guard game.

I‚Äôve been working on these entries a lot lately, and they‚Äôve become some of my go-to attacks. Give them a try, and let me know in the comments how they work for you!

Learn the Brutal Lateral Kneebar and Hiplock from Reversed Closed Guard

title: Tarikoplata Seminar at Fearless MMA (10.000 Subscribers)
description:
First of all, I would like to express my heartfelt gratitude to all of you for your amazing support! We have recently reached a major milestone by hitting 10,000 subscriptions, and it would not have been possible without each and every one of you. It truly means a lot to me that so many people have found value in the content that I am creating.

In celebration of this milestone, I wanted to share a new video with you as soon as possible. I understand that the quality may not be up to my usual standards, but given the short turnaround time, I hope that some of you will still find the details in this video useful. I want to deliver the best content possible, and I promise that I will continue to strive for excellence in everything that I do.

Additionally, I wanted to let you know that we are filming some more videos this Monday, and I am open to any suggestions that you may have. I value your feedback and I want to create content that is relevant and engaging to you. So, if you have any topics that you would like me to cover, please leave them in the comment section below. I will do my best to address them in future videos.

Once again, thank you all for your support and for being a part of this incredible community. I look forward to continuing to provide you with valuable content and growing together.

0:00 Kimura from Knee on Belly
1:57 Tarikoplata from Kimura
4:15 Finishing the Tarikoplata
6:01 Rolling Back Up into the Tarikoplata
8:45 Double Under Entry to Tarikoplata
11:34 Backwards Roll into the Tarikoplata
13:57 Knee Shield Entry to Tarikoplata
14:16 Collar Sleeve Entry to Tarikoplata
16:32 Lasso Counter to Tarikoplata
17:40 Top Turtle Entry to Tarikoplata
18:02 Top Deep Half Guard Counter to Tarikoplata

title: Switching from Darce Choke to Arm In North South Choke
description:
Hey guys! In this video we're looking at how I like to transition from the darce to the north south choke and this can be done in reverse as well. This is essentially just a arm triangle flipped the other way around. In that sense it's exactly the same finishing mechanics. The beauty of the north south choke is that it can be done with or without your opponents arm trapped. Though the last mentioned has a lot more control.

In this tutorial, I'll walk you through the steps of executing the Arm Triangle from the North South position. Whether you're a seasoned BJJ practitioner or a curious learner, this technique breakdown is for you.

We'll delve into the crucial aspects of timing and positioning, which are essential for a successful execution. Watch closely as I demonstrate the seamless transition into the Arm Triangle, catching opponents off guard.

title: Jiu Jitsu Dice Game
description:
2 minute rounds.
Roll two dices  for:

Submission mission
1. Eziekel choke
2. Cross choke
3. Wrist lock
4. Omoplata
5. Triangle
6. Gogoplata

Pact of punishment
1. Your back can‚Äôt touch the floor
2. You can only stand on one leg
3. No grips on opponents gi
4. No knees on the floor
5. No hands on the floor
6. You start mounted

title: Imanari Roll -ish from Squid Guard
description:
Here's a great way to sweep your opponent from squid guard by spinning under your opponent and entangling their legs. This opens up for a lot of fun positions and submissions. This movement has a lot of similarities to the Imanari roll which is perhaps mostly known for it's use from standing in NoGi events. The biggest difference movement wise would be that you don't lace the leg on top of their thigh. üòÑü§ôüèº

00:00 ‚Äì 3 targets
01:43 ‚Äì Block & drive/lift & rotate
02:29 ‚Äì Get & keep your opponent's hips on the mat
03:51 ‚Äì Get your chest on your opponent's torso
04:44 ‚Äì Connect to the upper body or to the lower body (takedowns)
05:53 ‚Äì Connect to the upper body or to the lower body (guard)
06:33 ‚Äì Head, hands & hips (lines of defense)
08:37 ‚Äì Rotate a bent limb or hyperextend a straight limb
09:17 ‚Äì Create space to defend & take away space to attack
10:09 ‚Äì Make their hips & shoulders face opposite directions
10:35 ‚Äì Use your head as a 5th limb
11:08 ‚Äì The feet are the hands of the legs
11:51 ‚Äì Stay out of your opponent's lap
12:38 ‚Äì Between the ear & shoulder and armpit & hip is a sacred space
13:23 ‚Äì Get behind the elbows
14:09 ‚Äì Stay in front of the knees
15:06 ‚Äì Never let someone grab your head
15:43 ‚Äì Just stand up
16:00 ‚Äì Keep your elbows close
16:27 ‚Äì Pro tip

00:00 1. Avoid most submissions from the bottom.
01:26 2. When on top, post preemptively or be ready to post.
02:41 3. Keep your feet in front of them. 
05:10 4. Turtle / get to your knees instead being on your back with no guard. 
07:16 5. Use the fake guard pull ankle pick (especially in the gi). 
08:07 6. Prevent defensive grips.
7. Careful when inverting (and minimise time spent inverted). 09:12

About me

Hi, I‚Äôm Priit Mihkelson from Estonia. I‚Äôm a Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu second degree black belt. I‚Äôve been involved in martial arts for 25 years and 18 of them devoted to Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, Grappling and MMA. I‚Äôm the head coach of the largest Estonian Grappling and MMA school 3D Treening.

My approach to training can best be described as ‚ÄùFunctional Minimalism‚Äù. It‚Äôs based on fundamental postures and movements that every grappler and MMA fighter needs to know.

Teaching is an art in itself and I think that I have a lot to contribute to this aspect of our sports.

Welcome to my youtube channel!

title: Rolling footage 3
description:
New video out üòé ...and this time I am rolling with Liisi Vaht!

Good warm up video because I have not rolled a while and now because of some interesting future endeavours I have to pick myself up again so to speak ...I found my 1. of January in a way üòÇ

Liisi (brown belt) is quite good and actually dangerous to roll with in a sense that if I move sloppy the she will punish me. She is also the reason that my gi-choke defense is somewhat on point because she was the one I developed it on by tapping quite a lot.

Enjoy!

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-

title: Beginners Guide: Types of Guard in Jiu Jitsu
description:
Closed guard, half guard, outside position guards, inside position guards, and leg entanglements form 5 major categories of guard you can play, each then containing a subset of guard styles.

The best approach is typically to master one of these guards first, then branching out to develop a broader game over several years.

This video is from the course "Foundations" on https://submeta.io : a course designed for beginners to understand jiu jitsu and develop a game.

title: Knee Cut to Leg Drag with Levi Jones Leary and Lachlan Giles
description:
Levi demonstrates how you can enter the leg drag from a knee cut entry, with live rolling footage using this technique at the end. From the new course "Leg Drag" By Levi Jones Leary and Lachlan Giles.

https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/leg-drag

The Leg Drag is a versatile guard pass that can be attained through outside leg passing, leg entanglements, crab ride, and chained with pressure passing.

In this course, Levi and Lachlan will teach you the leg drag in a few key segments: Entering the leg drag where we look to pass the line of the foot and turn our opponent's hips to face away; mid-stage leg drag where we look to beat the knee line and prevent a variety of defenses such as the high pummel; end-stage leg drag where we cover how to take control of your opponent's upper body and clear the legs to pass. 

Each segment has a detailed troubleshooting section to deal with the common issues you will encounter, and live footage of Levi and Lachlan using these techniques in rolling.

title: The Guard You Play Determines the Leg Locks You Like
description:
A good jiu jitsu game should consist of well connected positions, a case in point is that the type of guard you use to enter into leg locks will influence which particular leg locks positions, and leg locks you should aim to be proficient at.

For more on leg locks check out our huge range of courses at https://submeta.io/sets/leg-locks

title: Applying Submissions and When to Tap
description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
In this video, we discuss a topic of great importance to your own safety and well being as well as that of your training partners ‚Äî how to apply submissions and when to tap. It is immensely important that we understand that we must tap when we are caught in a submission and cannot escape. Leave it until you feel pain can often be too late.

description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
One of the worst mistakes you can make from the mount position is to attempt to push your opponent off with extended arms. Unfortunately, this is our natural instinct. In this video, we teach you how to take full advantage of this mistake by using it to transition to the armbar. The armbar, one of the most common submissions in grappling,  is a submission that pits our whole body against our opponent‚Äôs elbow joint.

Once our opponent is on the ground we take up the task of progressing to more dominant positions. Positional dominance is increased when we put our opponent in ever more dangerous positions and move closer to submission. In this video, we show you how to go from side control to the mount. The mount is a dangerous position for the person underneath, they are in a vulnerable spot and one mistake can lead to almost instant submission.

title: Escaping Side Control
description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
Side control is a position of danger. Our opponent can move to gain even more dominant positions (like the mount and back control) and we are always a few steps away from being submitted. When we are underneath side control our main objectives are to remain safe and to look to put our opponent back in the guard position. In this video, we cover a side control escape that will detail the proper way to frame, hip escape and recover the guard.

title: Armbar from Closed Guard
description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
The armbar from closed guard is one of the signature movements of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. The closed guard is a deceptive position, to the untrained eye, it appears as if the person on top is at great advantage. Happily, the person on the bottom actually has the inside track to the submission and it is the person on top who has to be careful not to commit a mistake. In this video, we show you how to take advantage of a common error and attain the armbar from closed guard.

Once we escape the mount finish in our opponents closed guard. When we are in closed guard we must seek to open the guard before we can proceed to improve our position and search for the submission. The closed guard is a position where we must take great care not to give our opponent the opportunity to sweep (to put us down and come on top) or to submit. In this video, we cover the dos and don‚Äôt of this position as well as detail one basic way to open the guard.

title: Escaping The Mount
description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
When our opponent is mount we are in danger and need to look to escape immediately. In self-defence or MMA being under mount is extremely dangerous because our opponent is free to strike and we cannot strike them back. In this video, we demonstrate how to escape to the half guard. This way of escaping is especially useful for smaller people escaping mount from a larger opponent.

title: Frames (Concept)
description:
Full Course Playlist ‚Üí https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDrQXekZsfYZfV1QZ4T5UkxLwFwQ12EbP
Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
In Jiujitsu there are few concepts of equivalent importance to those good framing. The reason is simple: Frames make us more efficient. If you frame poorly, you use¬†more energy and you tire quickly. When we understand how to use frames we multiply the force we can withstand and the force we can exert. We economise our¬†energy and we¬†greatly enhance our¬†ability to control the pace of the fight.

description:

Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
From the mount there are two common intuitive reactions that lead to bad outcomes for the person on bottom: Trying to push away (which we covered earlier) and trying to turn away. In this video, we cover taking the back from the mount which is made easier when our opponent turns away. We use a basic Americana attempt to force the reaction and then we use the chair sit technique to attain back control.

Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
Once we are in half guard we look to move to an even better and more secure position. When we arrive in half guard from the mount we have no frames in place and we carry our opponent's weight. So we must seek to build a base of frames that will enable us to create space and use less energy to maintain a more secure position.

description:

Find the Introduction course here ‚Üí  https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/introduction 
Working from a half guard with a solid frame structure in place, we look to turn the tables on our opponent with a sweep. This half guard sweep focuses on securing an underhook. The underhook enables us to control the all-important inside space. This gives us an advantage over our opponent because it allows us the opportunity to come up to our knees and put our opponent down on the mat.

title: Free course: Berimbolo | SUBMETA.io
description:
Go to https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles and get started watching the Free course on the berimbolo. This course will be free to watch until Dec 9 2022.

The berimbolo is one of the most popular techniques in modern BJJ. It's a staple of the dynamic featherweight division and a technique that has been foundational to the success of many legendary champions. In this course, we break down the base level berimbolo game plan, look to counter the common reactions to the bolo and then focus on the crab ride position.

title: Spider Guard: How to Isolate Their Arm
description: When you isolate the arm by separating the elbow from the hip you then can open up for attacks such as the triangle, or use it to drag their weight forward for sweeps. Check out the full course at https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles

title: Spider Guard (New Course)
description:
Spider guard use sleeve grips and the feet in the biceps to dominate control of the opponent's upper body. With the upper body control, the spider guard player uses the position to off-balance the opponent and set up a variety of submissions and sweeps. In this course, we cover the core concepts of this gi-based guard.

title: If I Could Know Only One Thing About Defending Heel Hooks
description:
This would be it! 
Hiding the heel will save you from getting caught in the heel hook in the first place, it is the most effective defense mechanism from beginner right through to ADCC competitor level.

If you want to learn some more advanced defense you can check out my course Defending Heel Hooks at https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses

title: Defending Heel Hooks (new course)
description:
Check it out here at
https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles

Heel hook defense is a relatively easy skill to learn, and defending in the correct manner is highly efficacious even against a skilled leg locker. As your defensive skills improve, the opponents heel hook attempt becomes an opportunity to either counter leg lock, look to establish a good passing position, or enter the berimbolo for a back take.

title: Reverse Closed Guard
description:
You can view the course here on SUBMETA
https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles/courses/reverse-closed-guard

The reverse closed guard (AKA Donkey Guard) is a great entry point for leg attacks, sweeps, and back takes. Use this position to prevent your opponents hips from freeing, whilst you gain dominant grips on their lower limbs. Once control is established you can then progress down the legs into a leg lock finish, or look to upgrade position.

This course covers entries to reverse closed guard, attacks from bottom, and attacks from top.

title: Weave and Cross Grip Pass (new course)
description:
The weave and cross grip pass each involve a cross grip on your opponents leg, the advantage of this is that you can prevent your opponent taking good guard retention posture as they cannot bring that knee towards their chest. 

This style of passing forms part of a pressure passing game and can be incredible tiring for your opponent to defend. Taking a weave or cross grip allows you to link between around the legs passing, smash pass, duckunders, and half guard passing. 

Check it out at https://submeta.io/@lachlangiles

title: New Course: Cat-Dog
description:
A symmetrical position in which each player is looking to either achieve the takedown or backtake. CatDog is when you each control your opponents far hip or far ankle, and can arise from takedown defense, escaping from bottom position, or during a berimbolo scramble. Understanding your options from here gives you great advantage at winning the scramble.

title: The Absolute BJJ Debate CH3 PART 6: Livia Giles S&C for ADCC 2019 (Main Lifting Sessions)
description:
BJJ is a relatively new, fast growing, sport. In this discussion series we explore the potential for using ideas from sports science and other performance sports to improve HOW we train and develop in Jiu-Jitsu.

In this chapter, we focus on the role of Strength and Conditioning in Jiu-Jitsu and how it differs for recreational versus competitive grapplers. In Part 6, we look at the main lifting sessions Liv performed prior to the 2019 ADCC European Trials. Her program included three lifting sessions per week from January to March 2019 with the goals for each month changing as she got closer to competition.


The panel includes:

Livia Giles (n√©e Gluchowska) is an Australian grappler and black belt in Brazilian jiu-jitsu. In 2019 she qualified for ADCC and has been an IBJJF World Champion (gi and no-gi) at blue, purple and brown belt. Before Jiu Jitsu, Livia competed at a high level in both gymnastics and track cycling. She is also a physiotherapist specialising in jiu-jitsu injuries and sits on the Australian Professional Boxing & Combat Sports Board.

Ben King is a Strength and Conditioning Coach at the Victorian Institute of Sport in Melbourne, Australia. He works with international elite athletes across a range of sports focused on achieving success at Commonwealth Games and Olympic level for Australia. In 2019, he helped Livia prepare for ADCC. As well as a big focus on combat sports such as BJJ, Wrestling, Judo and Karate, Ben also works with athletes in gymnastics, golf, racquet sports, basketball and shooting.

You can follow Ben on:Twitter: https://twitter.com/B_kingsc
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/b.king_sc/

Tom Crick is the Head of Track and Field Athletics at Aspire Academy in Qatar and a BJJ brown belt. He was previously the Director of Coaching and Athlete Development in Northern Ireland and worked for British Athletics in the run up to the London 2012 Olympics.

title: Learning BJJ: Sequences vs positional options (Lachlan Giles)
description: An important part of training is having the right approach for practicing techniques. Here I discuss whether you should be focusing on working sequences that may follow from a position you are in, or the many options that you have for your current positioning.

title: The right way to get feet on biceps position (Ariel Tabak and Lachlan Giles)
description:
http://lachlangiles.net/guard-retention-anthology-deal

The Guard Retention Anthology: Around and Under is finally here. This collaboration between Ariel Tabak and myself has taken 9 months to make, and made an enormous difference to my game, I hope it does for you too. Expect it to take some time to develop as it will most likely be a different approach to what you were using before, but I can guarantee that once you fully adopt this style it will be a game changer for you.

This really is different to what I believe is currently out there and I am actually quite ashamed how bad I think my open guard retention was before working with Ariel, be prepared to hate some of your training partners who start using it :)

The instructional is split up into two sets: Around and Under, and Through the legs. Each share a common first chapter on general guard retention principles, and then about 8 hours of unique content.

Around and Under covers general concepts and principles, around the legs retention, under the legs retention, initiating the first grip, turning defense to offense, and narrated rolling.

Through the Legs (to be released next month) covers general concepts and principles, headquarters, cross knee through, knee shield, half guard variants, the smash pass, late stage recovery, and narrated rolling.

The content is in depth but really aimed for anyone willing to dive deep into what good guard retention is, it is certainly more similar to the guard retention you would see at the lighter weight divisions rather than heavy, as they tend to have the more impassable guards. That is not to say that heavier people cannot use it, we both think this is the best style to play and recommend all take this approach and do the recommended mobility work to make it as effective as possible. There are definitely options if you are less mobile, and a good place to start there would be the through the legs section, particularly the half guard and knee shield variants. However for optimum guard retention we recommend not settling at this close to mid range, and continuing to push your opponent back layers and develop good retention and further distance (open guards).

Save an extra 10% with the code LACHLAN10 or use the link here to give me an extra cut for the referral.

title: Why the hip escape is bad for guard retention (Lachlan Giles and Ariel tabak)
description:

http://lachlangiles.net/guard-retention-anthology-deal

Ever since Ariel Tabak explained the concept of not hip escaping, and using the high pummel to retain guard, my guard retention improved immensely. In this video we discuss why the hip escape is bad.

The content is in depth but really aimed for anyone willing to dive deep into what good guard retention is, it is certainly more similar to the guard retention you would see at the lighter weight divisions rather than heavy, as they tend to have the more impassable guards. That is not to say that heavier people cannot use it, we both think this is the best style to play and recommend all take this approach and do the recommended mobility work to make it as effective as possible. There are definitely options if you are less mobile, and a good place to start there would be the through the legs section, particularly the half guard and knee shield variants. However for optimum guard retention we recommend not settling at this close to mid range, and continuing to push your opponent back layers and develop good retention and further distance (open guards).

Each set is $127, with through the legs due next month. Save an extra 10% with the code LACHLAN10 or use the link here to give me an extra cut for the referral.

title: The Guard Retention Anthology: Ariel Tabak and Lachlan Giles
description:
The Guard Retention Anthology is finally here. This collaboration between Ariel Tabak and myself has taken 9 months to make, and made an enormous difference to my game, I hope it does for you too. Expect it to take some time to develop as it will most likely be a different approach to what you were using before, but I can guarantee that once you fully adopt this style it will be a game changer for you. 

This really is different to what I believe is currently out there and I am actually quite ashamed how bad I think my open guard retention was before working with Ariel, be prepared to hate some of your training partners who start using it :)

The instructional is split up into two sets: Around and Under, and Through the legs. Each share a common first chapter on general guard retention principles, and then about 8 hours of unique content.

Around and Under covers general concepts and principles, around the legs retention, under the legs retention, initiating the first grip, turning defense to offense, and narrated rolling.

Through the Legs covers general concepts and principles, headquarters, cross knee through, knee shield, half guard variants, the smash pass, late stage recovery, and narrated rolling.

The content is in depth but really aimed for anyone willing to dive deep into what good guard retention is, it is certainly more similar to the guard retention you would see at the lighter weight divisions rather than heavy, as they tend to have the more impassable guards. That is not to say that heavier people cannot use it, we both think this is the best style to play and recommend all take this approach and do the recommended mobility work to make it as effective as possible. There are definitely options if you are less mobile, and a good place to start there would be the through the legs section, particularly the half guard and knee shield variants. However for optimum guard retention we recommend not settling at this close to mid range, and continuing to push your opponent back layers and develop good retention and further distance (open guards).

Each set is $127, Save an extra 10% with the code LACHLAN10 or use the link here to give me an extra cut for the referral.

https://bjjfanatics.com/collections/all/products/the-guard-retention-anthology-by-lachlan-giles-ariel-tabak?rfsn=2691516.3afc7d

If you have any questions ask them here and Ariel and I will be happy to answer.

title: The Absolute BJJ Debate CH3: Strength and Conditioning for BJJ (Livia Giles) PART 3
description:
BJJ is a relatively new, fast growing, sport. In this discussion series we explore the potential for using ideas from sports science and other performance sports to improve HOW we train and develop in Jiu-Jitsu.

In this chapter, we focus on the role of Strength and Conditioning in Jiu-Jitsu and how it differs for recreational versus competitive grapplers. In Part 3 we continue to answer questions from Instagram with a focus on S&C for the recreational grappler. Topics include:

How specific does my S&C program need to be?
How often should I change my program? 
What are some of the biggest S&C mistakes to avoid?

The episode finishes with some S&C training recommendations for the recreational grappler.

The panel includes:

Livia Giles (n√©e Gluchowska) is an Australian grappler and black belt in Brazilian jiu-jitsu. In 2019 she qualified for ADCC and has been an IBJJF World Champion (gi and no-gi) at blue, purple and brown belt, and a silver medalist at World No Gi and World Pro at black belt. Before Jiu Jitsu, Livia competed at a high level in both gymnastics and track cycling. She is also a physiotherapist specialising in jiu-jitsu injuries and sits on the Victorian Professional Boxing & Combat Sports Board.

Ben King is a Strength and Conditioning Coach at the Victorian Institute of Sport in Melbourne, Australia. He works with international elite athletes across a range of sports focused on achieving success at Commonwealth Games and Olympic level for Australia. In 2019, he helped Livia prepare for ADCC. As well as a big focus on combat sports such as BJJ, Wrestling, Judo and Karate, Ben also works with athletes in gymnastics, golf, racquet sports, basketball and shooting.

Tom Crick is the Head of Track and Field Athletics at Aspire Academy in Qatar and a BJJ brown belt. He was previously the Director of Coaching and Athlete Development in Northern Ireland and worked for British Athletics in the run up to the London 2012 Olympics.

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

title: 2018 Thailand Training Camp with Lachlan Giles Vlog
description:
BOOK NOW for 2019 camp: Early bird special is available.  http://absolutemmathailand.com/lachlan-giles-camp/

Lachlan is a world renowned coach and competitor from Absolute MMA St Kilda, Australia, leading a team which has produced standout grapplers such as two-time Polaris champion Craig Jones, 3-time World Champion Livia Giles and Kit Dale. His coaching has gained online recognition with over 2 million views on his YouTube channel. 

June 30th to July 6th, 2019 is your chance to learn cutting edge technique from on of the best coaches in the world during this intensive training camp at Absolute MMA Thailand in Phuket, Thailand.

Aside from the training, we will make your trip to Thailand as easy, enjoyable and exciting as possible by offering:

Delicious Thai welcome dinner and farewell dinner
Two 1-hour sports massages
Included breakfasts
A  Lachlan Giles rash guard
Plus daily tours including:

Full-day long boat island tours
Trips to the beautiful Nai Harn beach and others
Shopping at night markets
Night out to Bangla Road in Patong
Visit to the famous Big Buddha
Optional Extras:

Private 1-on-1 sessions with Lachlan 
Optional tours including Muay Thai fight shows
ATV tours
Zipline

Lachlan is a world renowned coach and competitor from Absolute MMA St Kilda, Australia, leading a team which has produced standout grapplers such as two-time Polaris champion Craig Jones, 3-time World Champion Livia Giles and Kit Dale. His coaching has gained online recognition with over 2 million views on his YouTube channel. 

June 30th to July 6th, 2019 is your chance to learn cutting edge technique from on of the best coaches in the world during this intensive training camp at Absolute MMA Thailand in Phuket, Thailand.

Aside from the training, we will make your trip to Thailand as easy, enjoyable and exciting as possible by offering:

Delicious Thai welcome dinner and farewell dinner
Two 1-hour sports massages
Included breakfasts
A  Lachlan Giles rash guard
Plus daily tours including:

Full-day long boat island tours
Trips to the beautiful Nai Harn beach and others
Shopping at night markets
Night out to Bangla Road in Patong
Visit to the famous Big Buddha
Optional Extras:

Private 1-on-1 sessions with Lachlan 
Optional tours including Muay Thai fight shows
ATV tours
Zipline

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My No Gi Chokes DVD here: Focusing on the guillotine, arm in guillotine, anaconda, darce, Japanese necktie, North South choke, and how to link these chokes together.

You can check out a detailed instructional on my butterfly, shin to shin, single X, X guard game on through the Grapplers Guide. There is also heaps of content from other world class instructors!

I have a GI half guard seminar available for just $17.50. Get that here:
https://gdf.thinkific.com/courses/lachlan-giles-half-guard-seminar


Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!
https://grapplersguide.com/

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!
https://grapplersguide.com/

He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

title: Half guard seminar: The complete underhook game (removed, see description for new hosting platform)
description:
Sorry this has been removed by YouTube as they discontinued paid content. If you already purchased on youtube you can still view.

I have a new half guard DVD available through BJJ Fanatics. It has 11 hours of content and is very comprehensive and covers all different types of half guard that I play. You can check that out here:

https://bjjfanatics.com/products/the-half-guard-anthology-by-lachlan-giles

Otherwise the seminar is available here: 
https://gdf.thinkific.com/courses/lachlan-giles-half-guard-seminar

IMPORTANT CONCEPTS
0:13 Where to place the underhook
3:46 Getting on your side
4:15 Turning the hips (pressure the knee)
5:41 Always try to bump your opponent forward, and move yourself lower relative to them
UNDERHOOK SERIES KNEELING
7:53 Ideal half guard sweep from knee shield
13:26 Dealing with both crossface and underhook to set up knee shield
15:11 Dealing with the whizzer by rolling under
19:00 Preventing a successful backstep by holding the far pants
19:52 Recovering your underhook when they have the underhook (no crossface)
21:14 When they post on the mat to prevent the roll under- take the back
23:04 Recover from tight crossface/underhook using Z guard
26:13 When they hide their leg from being trapped

UNDERHOOK SERIES STANDING
29:13 When they turn their knee towards mount
30:34 Countering the standing passer/knee cut
33:55 Dealing with cross lapel choke
35:40 Single leg from standing posture
40:01 Saggioro sweep (lapel head through the middle)

COUNTERING THE BACKSTEP
44:05 prevent their leg from reaching the ground
44:24 Prevent the hips moving back, take the back
45:00 Using your hooks to sweep
46:27 The super lockdown
48:42 The double leg pinch

THE DOGFIGHT
50:07 The rollthrough
52:09 Basic takedown and single leg
53:19 The leg drag
54:41 Limp arm

MISC- Guillotine defence
55:43 Countering the guillotine, roll on top
56:59 Countering the guillotine, turn the hip
58:39 Countering the guillotine, head positioning

ROLLING
58:59 Roll 1 just trying to use half guard
1:04:42 Roll 2 just trying to use half guard
1:10:40 Roll 3 just trying to use half guard

title: Choi Bar from Z-Guard (Craig Jones)
description:
In this video, Absolute MMA St Kilda Coach and EBI Semi-Finalist Craig Jones demonstrates a technique from his new 'Z-Guard Masterclass' (with Kit Dale). You can purchase the DVD at KitDaleTraining.com. 

Note: the video quality for the actual DVD is much better.

Follow Craig on Instagram: 

https://www.instagram.com/jiujitsutravels/

NOTE:

This is an unpaid endorsement. Head Coach Lachlan Giles, the video's creator, and Absolute MMA St Kilda received no money for promoting this DVD. We just think the DVD is very good and we are keen to help Craig earn a bit of cash.

title: Coach Livia Gluchowska has been awarded her black belt!
description:
Absolute St Kilda coach and 2016 Brown Belt World Champion Livia Gluchowska was awarded her black belt by Professors Thiago Steffanuti and Lachlan Giles. 

Over 70 teammates and friends turned up for the ceremony including 10 (11 including Liv) of Australia's top black belt competitors. 

From all of your teammates and students, congratulations Liv!

He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!
https://grapplersguide.com/

description:

Email Craig to book a private lesson in Melbourne or host him for a seminar: craigjonesbjj@gmail.com

http://lachlangiles.net/grapplers-guide-deal

I have a GI half guard seminar available for just $17.50. Get that here:
https://gdf.thinkific.com/courses/lachlan-giles-half-guard-seminar


Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!
https://grapplersguide.com/

Lachlan Giles reached the semi-finals of EBI 5. 

Click here to sign-up for a free trial class: 

http://absolutemma.net.au/book-a-free...

Check out our sponsor MA1: 

http://www.ma1.com.au/bjj/

About Head Instructor Lachlan Giles:

Lachlan earned his BJJ black belt in July 2012 and is the 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion and has competed at 4 World Championship events.

In 2014 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia‚Äôs most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2015, he competed in the ADCC Championship. 

In 2016 he won the ADCC Asian Trials and earned a spot at the 2017 ADCC Championship which will be held in Helsinki, Finland.

Outside of BJJ, he works as a physiotherapist, and is currently completing his PhD at La Trobe University.

Lachlan is a second degree BJJ black belt. He is the 2017 IBJJF No-Gi World Championship Bronze Medallist, 2014 Australian Jiu-Jitsu Grand Prix Champion, multiple time Pan Pacific and Victorian Jiu Jitsu Champion. He has represented Australia twice at ADCC, the most prestigious submission grappling competition in the world, represented Australia three times at the World Pro Championships and competed at the Eddie Bravo Invitational where he submitted former ADCC Champion Rani Yahya.

In 2014 and 2017 he completed a clean sweep of the black belt division at Australia's most prestigious competition, the Pan Pacific Championships, winning 4 gold medals. In 2016 Lachlan was ranked as the number 12 lightweight BJJ competitor in the world. He is also the 2016 Australian Freestyle Wrestling Champion.

He also works as a physiotherapist and in 2016 completed his PhD.

My butterfly and single leg X game can be found on the grapplers guide!

title: How I started the most reviewed Jitsu gym in the world.
description: I started repping AJJ over 10 years ago, and every step of the way I was met with objections to my conviction. Today I have proof AJJ works, is fundamentally different in the way we teach grappling, and we introduce more people to jiujitsu than any other academy in the entire world. This is all a culmination of a vision I saw for jiujitsu's future, one where Americans can train and teach in an environment that has its priorities in order. I'm opening up these systems to a small and vetted group of gym owners to contribute and benefit from this movement. Just Dm me the word GYM or go to LEGIONAJJ.COM to apply. (We are only accepting a limited number of qualified applicants)

How I attract new members to my gym.
description: Im making this video series on owning and operating jiu-jitsu academies for all the people who love jiujitsu and are looking for a vehicle to orient their lifestyle and income around it. Jiu-jitsu gyms are great businesses with high returns and low start-up costs, so they make great starter-projects for entrepreneurs who love jiu-jitsu. This content is free but I do have a partner program for people who would like to model my systems and business strategies. IF you are a gym owner who is looking to scale their member numbers or an aspiring gym owner looking to make his mark in the world, we will work with you to make sure you have the best chances of success. I want jiu-jitsu to thrive and have as many people exposed to it as possible which means we need more gyms! At the end of the day its US the gym owners who grow jiu-jitsu and awareness. We are the tip of the spear so I want to arm any able bodied men and women to challenge themselves and make great money while training with your buddies. You can contact us through the form on https://legionajj.com/

title: The only sustainable way to make money with jiujitsu.
description:
There‚Äôs a really romantic idea that you can train and compete in jiujitsu and eventually you can make a living grappling.

The truth is the only way to thrive in jiujitsu and have it be your ‚Äújob‚Äù is to operate a jiujitsu academy. It‚Äôs not even important to have a ton of competitive accolades. You can skip the grind of 10 years of brutal competition and use that time to establish business fundamentals and learn how to provide true value.

I was the highest paid grappler on earth for a a number of years and even that is dwarfed by the potential of one physical location providing the environment for people to enjoy jiujitsu.

My point here is that you can learn how to establish a recurring revenue business while being around the sport you love. And it‚Äôs really not as hard as it looks. Just like jiujitsu you only need a mentor and learning resources

I‚Äôve spent the last few years building systems around how to operate an academy in the modern world, and I want to share this with those who want to also step to up to the highest order of grappling industry. Which is to be the facilitator of mat space AND grappling knowledge.

Dm me the word ACADEMY if you already are trying to create a thriving gym or if you are interested in becoming a gym owner one day. And check out what we‚Äôve built at @legion_ajj and @jiu_jitsu_x to see what I‚Äôm all about with grappling business. or go to https://legionajj.com/

title: Getting A Butterfly Grip And Maximizing Pressure From Smash Half
description:
Laying on someone? Yeah, that's easy. Mastering top pressure? That is truly an art form. 

Click play to learn high level details on how to maximize shoulder pressure and really stick your opponent in place.

title: Using A Stiff Arm To Recover From Speed Passes
description:
Sometimes rather than using pressure to smash your leg together, your opponent managed to hit a clean speed pass that either quickly rotated your body out of the way or allowed them to quickly maneuver themselves around your legs.

In this situation, the technique may differ, but the concepts remain the same: create a stiff arm that allows you to get up to your bottom elbow to hip escape away and create space.

Watch the video above to learn how to do exactly that. Go to jiujitsux.com for more

title: Beat Annoying Lapel Guards!  EASY Counter Just Stomp The Leg - Lapel Slayer
description:
Lapel Lasso can be one most annoying and tricky guards to pass. But why would you spend all this time and effort trying to work out of the position when you could just step on your opponent and pass like butter?

The trick is to loosen the hold before you get wrapped up too tight in the lasso. By stomping on the far leg you're giving yourself the opportunity to open up the guard and start working your passing. 

This is ONE of the ways to destroy Lapel Guard. Get more passes here:
https://jiujitsux.com/lapel-slayer

title: How to wrestle in bjj by using the gi to its maximum potential (no one has caught on yet)
description:
Worm wrestling is all about FEAR. Speaking of fear, I would be afraid to death to miss the last day of the Lapel Encyclopedia Anniversary SALE. Go to https://lapelguard.com and grab a discounted copy that comes with the Worm Wrestling Update (Chapter 14). The Encyclopedia goes on sale very rarely, so save the 32.4% NOW.

 Worm wrestling is all about FEAR, manipulation and control. The knowledge from Chapter 14 of the Lapel Encyclopedia will infest your opponent's mind, making them feel unsafe, insecure. When they are insecure they will make more mistakes, they will freeze, without even executing the feeble maneuvers they had planned.
 
That is a bold claim, so let me paint this picture for you. You are a smart person, you invested in the Encyclopedia. You had 3 chapters teach you the concepts, 2 were about passing and submissions and about 8 were about playing guard‚Ä¶ Now‚Ä¶ 
 
You're rolling or competing and you tiger swipe the lapel away from your opponent, you grab it and you start doing your thing, twisting that piece of cloth and foam around your and their legs in unspeakable ways. Your opponent is no slouch, he/she recognizes what's going on, knows that to push towards you means sure defeat as you're quite nifty and ready with your lapel trickery.
 
That's why your opponent lets fear take over and they start pushing against you, backing away, trying to make themselves small. They're leaning back, posturing up, trying desperately to break your expert grips.
 
Then when they think they almost got away, your foot shoots out from the worm hole, they see a small opening and then... you're on your knees. Oh god. They panic, they do a desperate sprawl, but it doesn't work! You got to a wrestling position WITH the lapel. Now they're getting pulled up, like a child rolling with an adult and the tornado starts. You're off-balancing them, they're jumping around until the ground comes closer. Bam. They're on the ground. ‚ÄúF%$#! Ok, that was unexpected, he got on top, it's just 2 points.‚Äù That thought jumps from one neuron to the other in 0.3 seconds and then it hits them! You STILL have the lapel grip and you've also flanked their guard. You worm wrestled them and then used the same lapel to get a devastating start for your passing sequences.
 
Now, your opponent's anguish is complete. Fear infiltrated their head and even if they recover, the next time you grab their lapel... they will know how much they don't know. But you knew what you have to learn. You chose knowledge over fear and that knowledge triumphs over fear and  gets you... victory. 

Only in the Lapel Encyclopedia, can you learn how to do this https://lapelguard.com

title: How to do the Leg Drag pass in 2020 (its changed) - Keenanonline.com
description:
How has the leg drag changed? Let's answer that with a more important question...

... Why did the leg drag HAVE to change? 

Since the leg drag burst onto the scene last decade, taking the crown as one of the most utilized and effective catalysts to the guard pass, guard players everywhere have been working endlessly to destroy it. 

And now, in 2020, the conventional leg drag position has been exposed as having 3 main weaknesses. 

Those weaknesses being...

1. A strong De La Riva hook with a pant sleeve grip.
2. The hamstring strength of an opponent reluctant to let you drag the leg across the body.
3. Your opponent's ability to counter, by passing their other leg over your body, stopping your advancements and opening up an opportunity to regain guard. 

Now you know why the leg drag had to change, hit that play button and learn how the leg drag in 2020 has, quite literally, squashed those problems.

description:

Topics discussed include how Craig got started in Jiu-Jitsu, his education in psychology, why he hates training in the gi, how to make money in Jiu-Jitsu if you‚Äôre not a blackbelt world champion, and the very unimpressive criminal backgrounds of Josh, Keenan, and Craig. Keenan tells a story about the time he experienced two SWAT raids in the same day and Craig talks about people getting his names tattoo‚Äôd on their broken ankles. They shared their thoughts on the topic of bowing to pictures on the wall. Big thanks to @craigjonesbjj for taking the time to be the first Matburn Podcast guest. Thanks to Sam the Tax Guy and Line Tax Services for their continued support, as well as Tap Cancer Out for their massive efforts to make the world a better place funding the fight against cancer nationwide.

title: Matburn Ep 8 - The Koi Pond Episode
description: Josh and Keenan talk in depth about skin infections and proper etiquette when it comes to training while you have some funk growing on your body. Ringworm, impetigo, staph, mat herps, etc... don't train when you have shit on yourself. They talked about the legend that is Kyle Maynard, congenital quadriplegic super hero who can do anything that any other full-able-bodied person. From there, they talked about the challenge of trying to control Kyle in training and some of Kyle's unique jiu-jitsu attacks based on his body type. They talked a little bit about how to recover from injuries, as well as the ideal class structure regarding warm-ups, technique, and sparring time. Huge thanks to our sponsors Mariana's Open, the World Series of Jiu-Jitsu, and Sam the Tax Guy (Line Tax Services) www.linetax.net, 913-353-4300. Matburn listeners get 50% off their initial tax service.

title: The Matburn Podcast Ep. 6 - with Keenan Cornelius and Josh Hinger
description: On episode 6, we talked about the good old penny-pinching travel days when we would try to get to tournaments by the cheapest and most uncomfortable means possible. Arm-rest battles on airplanes. We talked about scam artists and the most recent scam artist story which claimed adcc competitor @pichaelmerez as a victim. We briefly touched on the gi vs nogi debate and whether it‚Äôs optimal to specialize in one or the other, or to do both. We took a moment to remind everyone what a badass JT Torres is as he is preparing to face off against one of the most savage competitors on the planet, Vagnar Rocha. Lastly, we talked about the implosion of nogi jiu-jitsu and whether it is devolving into a game of wrestling with leg locks. Oh, and we talked about the failure of Mantis Guard. Big thanks to our sponsors @marianasopen, @worldseriesofjiujitsu, and Line Tax Services.

description:
* https://thewormguard.com/ *

The wormguard is an obssession that I first shared in my DVD, it sold a bunch of copies and it was really cool.

But now, we're in 2018 and that means 2 things: 
1. DVDs are slowly becoming obsolete and it's time for BJJ instructionals to be available on all devices. Why wait on a plastic disk to fly half way around the world, when you can just download the content, like right now. 

2. The worm guard also became more, those sweeps that made the worm guard famous evolved. Squid guard became a thing and is now available as bonus footage.

title: Important Jiu-jitsu Concepts - TEMPO and how to gain it. Part 1 of 6 KEENANONLINE.COM
description:
Lately I feel like a lot of important concepts like this are being lost on students. Partially because nobody is teaching it. But also because there's not a lot of native English speakers that can explain it clearly. This is The first part of a series which can be found on my website https://keenanonline.com/ At this point in jiujitsu I feel there is SO much focus on individual techniques. Its like people trying to learn are just randomly being handed puzzle pieces without the full image as reference. So over the last year I've been compiling an archive of what I'm calling Sequence Based Skill Development. I think of it like instead of puzzle pieces, I'm just handing you a bunch of small completed puzzles! I Believe it takes a lot of the guesswork out learning the complex ideas of jiujitsu. Im putting a ton (literally if it was all pennies it would weigh one ton) of money into revamping my site over this next month to be more organized with this philosophy of teaching. I would love it if you guys came through and let me know what you think of this teaching ideology

title: A New Guard Emerges - Krab Guard - KEENANONLINE.COM  exclusive technique ft. Andre Galvao
description:
Coming straight from my laboratory deep in the Atos HQ, I give you KRAB GUARD. a tasty little morsel of what I know will become quite a extensive guard system. Ideal for people who don't like open guard, think of KRAB GUARD as secondary half guard, just backwards and better. And with less shoulder pressure in your face. The more the push, the tighter it becomes , like a chinese finger trap, once the krab guard gets a hold of you there is no letting go. I started working on this a few days ago but I was so excited about it I had to share it with you all.

If you would like to see more of these innovative technique videos, sign up and subscribe at https://keenanonline.com/ to keep learning my original techniques and methods.

title: Omoplata Berimbolo - OMOPALOOZA.COM
description: Get the Digital Download here http://omopalooza.com/ The omopalooza instructional has been out for a few days and so far everyone is loving Andris's super detailed instruction, a few days ago we posted  self defense bonus. But today in a more serious application, andris shows us the omoplata berimbolo. I've seen him hit this ad nauseam. I personally strugge against this technique while training with Andris all the time. Its fast, its slick, its brutal yet elegant, and Andris depicts this in painstaking detail. Absorb this. Its a must-know. You can get the entire instruction series at http://omopalooza.com/  Get it today and add these devious tactics to your game today, and please, once you master the omoplata, dont wreck your training partners too badly.

title: Defeating an Armed Attacker, Bonus self defense technique from Omopalooza.com
description: Andris Brunovskis's fantastical Omopalooza experience is now available! Go check it out at www.omopalooza.com with more omoplata sweeps submissions and counters than our feeble mortal minds could have ever imagined, Andris has pushed the limits of the human shoulder, attacking it in this creative and vicious series of rotator wrenching shoulder crunching omoplata specific techniques. Andris's philosophy on omoplatas transcends the the idea of of omoplata as a submission and puts emphasis on it as a control position of incredible dominance and grace. Attacking berimbolos, chokes, calf slicers and armbars . With 90+ minutes of high level instruction follow Andris through its whacky and whimsical world of this obscure and under utilized technique. Known as the "omoplata terror" "renown holder of the shoulder" "white chocolate" "sniper" and many other names his opponents have given him out of fear of his sauvity and aggressive style. Go check out this instructional. I fully believe in his techniques, and this comes with a bonus self defense portion which is hilarious but painfully effective, Www.omopalooza.com

title: Rolling with 30 people in a row no rest - Keenan Cornelius
description: I try to do this at all my seminars. It doesn't always go well... for the black belt rolls from this seminar you can hit up https://keenanonline.com/ there you will find more sparring sessions and over 300 technique videos. I think it was thirty, a few rolls happened before recording started, didn't get to roll with everyone at the seminar but i think i got to train with about 80%. the rules for this engagement were First to score or submit! except I get to stay in win or lose :} make sure to check out my gi sponsor at http://doordie.com/ they make this sharp black gi you see here.
